reviewText: The kids loved it!
My copy is so tattered, worn and so loved.  A well done plot on how it's sometimes better to get along, than to try to work the problem.
summary: probably my favorite children's book of all

reviewText: My aunt bought me this book in 1962 - I was ten years old. My younger sister and I read the poems and loved them all. We marked the book up by writing in it by trying to copy all the great illustrations in it. My dad, sister, and myself would read about Paul Revere's ride and The Common Cormorant and then talk about what we read. My father's favorite poem in it was The Children's Hour. When I was in my 30's I bought myself another copy of it. Both my sister and my dad have passed and this poetry book brings back all the memories that I shared with them. I'm 64 now and still remember the words to my favorite poems in this anthology. It will definitely make memories for any child who is lucky enough to get a copy.
summary: The Best Poetry Books For Children And Adults

reviewText: This was a wonderful book so I got it as a gift for my niece. It's a very thick book full of different poems on many topics. You will be able to find many that you love.
Looking for a Louis Untermeyer book  from the 1980s and this was not the one,
Its lovely just what my husband was looking for and how he had remembered it

Dr. Seuss has some really brilliant books.  This book is just a so-so Dr. Seuss.  As a parent who is familiar with about 15 Dr. Seuss books, this is one of my least favorite books.
The book attempts to teach the child what "Up" means.  There is a terrific amount of repetition, and the cleverness in the rhyming and pictures is not "Up!" to par with other Dr. Seuss books.
My 6-month old children are too young to understand this book, but I think that Mommy and Daddy will tire of the book long before they have gotten the very simple and trivial message in this book : what is the difference between Up and Down ...
It's Dr. Seuss. what's not to like. A great story that I remember reading as a kid that I am now reading to my child!
Childhood favorite my grand enjoy
Ordered two of these for my great grandchildren. My kids loved this book.
Like it

What else is there to say about a classic?  I made a box of childhood memories for a high school senior, and this is one of the things I included, as all my kids have heard this story so many times, as did I and my brothers in our childhoods.
Classic children's story
my wife had never heard of this book so i bought it for her birthday.

This is a feel good, helpful story about trains that don't have their own section in the Target toy department.

My 3-year-old daughter loves trains. And Thomas is getting a little annoying.

This book is wonderful on so many levels. I love that heroine is a girl train. The message is great -- think positive and you can achieve. We've only had it a short time, but daughter quotes the book back to me already.

It's a joy to read out loud -- it's very well written. And the illustrations evoke a different time -- when kids were kids and not just consumers that need to be enticed into buying a toy or a book or a DVD collection.
summary: Get Away from the Commercialism of Thomas!!

reviewText: My kids go nuts over this book b/c each page has a silly picture, and they can respond, "Yes!" It's fun to watch my 4-year-old recite it from memory to my 2-year-old and hear him respond, "Yes!" and "No!" at the appropriate places! This is a fantastic book!
my twin toddlers love this book - the train-shaped board book is interesting for them to explore with their little hands, and the story just long enough to hold thier attention

reviewText: When Cornelius' mother quizzes him on whether he's ready for bed, he answers honestly each time. Yes, Cornelius has fed the fish...chocolate chip cookies! Yes, Cornelius has put on his pajamas...and a pair of rollerskates and a scuba mask! Preschoolers and kindergardeners will laugh at Cornelius' silly antics. Adults will appreciate whimsy in illustrations: the fishes' shocked looks, the titles on Cornelius' books (We, we, we all the way home, Where the Wild Pigs Are, and If you Give a Mouse a Pig just to name a few). Great for encouraging dialogue during a one-on-one read-aloud session.

As a parent of three, one of the most important things I can give my children is motivation.
The attitude that he or she CAN DO ANYTHING IF THEY THINK THEY CAN DO IT.
By reading this story over and over again, the message will go into their conscious and subconscious mind and my hope is that they will follow their dreams and become all they are able to become.
Zev Saftlas, Author of Motivation That Works: How to Get Motivated and Stay Motivated
What better gift can a parent give their child than believing in them?

This is an appropriate book for kids less than 2 years old.  It is a vocabulary book that simply lists a bunch of pictures and the words that goes with the pictures.  It lists many of the common every day items that you would find in a house.  It is not clever and I dare say, it's not _really_ a Dr. Seuss book The Illustration quality is WAY BELOW AVERAGE compared to ANY picture book for young children.
Like many books, if its the first one your parents give to you, you will probably love the book.  I believe that this is why some other reviewers have raved about this book.
Great book. I remember reading this when I was little and now I am reading it to my daughter. Love all the memories it brings back. What's not to like.

reviewText: This futuristic society in downtown Chicago where people are split into factions (kind of like Districts in Hunger Games) based on an aptitude test for honesty, courage, knowledge, peace, and service was engaging. People can choose whichever group they want to join, but they pretty much stick with that group for the rest of their lives, even if their parents are in another faction. What sounds like a good idea at first ends up being dystopia, of course. I was intrigued by this young Christian author, and she did not disappointed me.

The first book was my favorite for sure!

reviewText: Another excellent book by Hillerman!

Great.
As with all the Tony Hillerman books, a good read, a great mystery, and fabulously accurate background that flows, unnoticed, into the story.

They're all good. Some better than others, perhaps. This book did the trick for me. I don't really know which is my favorite by H. or which one I'd start someone with. I wasn't really dissappointed with the previous books like some reviewers, but as I read this one, I seem to recall feeling like it was a pleasant surprise. I have some personal experiences that draw me to the land up there. I especially love the descriptions of the land as Bernie gazes out (looking southeast from the Chuskas into what some consider desolation, if I recall correctly). Good stuff.

The Wailing Wind is the latest effort from Tony Hillerman. It's classic Hillerman: a fine story, well-conceived and carefully put together, with a fair share of suspense to keep the pages turning quickly. Hillerman fans will recognize their favorite cast of characters; this edition sees Jim Chee, Joe Leaphorn, fledgeling officer "Bernie" Manuelito, and relatively new character Louisa Bourbonette team up to unearth the connection between a new homicide victim and an old missing person case.
  The prose is well-written, and reads quickly. The story is quite good, but not his finest (I personally recommend A Thief of Time). In The Wailing Wind, we get to learn whether Jim Chee and Bernie will take a few fumbling steps toward a budding romance, or whether Hillerman keeps us on the hook for another year. If you're a Hillerman fan, or if you're not yet, I think you'll like this story a lot.
summary: Another Fine Insallment of the Hillerman Series

reviewText: I had thought I had read and re-read all (and I mean ALL) of Hillerman's novels until I chanced on this one.  It had been my opinion that Wailing Wind was the absolute best of the series; however, I must slightly revise my list.  People of Darkness is fantastic and very suspenseful -- Chee at his best.  While I had arrived at the identity of the main bad guy about mid-novel, I was not sure how the story would proceed.  It just kept building and building to the climax and the climax is pure Hillerman.  While the Navajo may not remember Mr. Hillerman as we do, I must believe that he is keeping the Great Spirit hughly entertained.
Tony Hillerman is a top notch story teller

Darker than other Leaphorn/Chee novels.  Wanders a bit but you soon realize the sidetrips are necessary to the main plot.  The bad guy is Really Bad!  The ending came as a complete surprise.  There is a comment about the Navajo losing their singers because the younger generation is not as family-oriented (drawn to the "White side"?) as years ago.  The same is happening to the Cherokee language -- not being taught or learned.
summary: Buy it - Read it - Enjoy it.

reviewText: Great.
Glad to have Hillerman on CD so I can enjoy the book on my travels.

"The Dark Wind" is an excellent read. In fact, it is just as good the second time around.  If you haven't enjoyed Hillerman yet, start with "Blessing Way" and go from there.  You will happily buy every Leaphorn/Chee book as well as everything else TH wrote.  As you can tell, I have always enjoyed Hillerman's work.  I like the Lt. Leaphorn character better than Jim Chee.  I guess that is because Leaphorn is more mature and more thoughtful and more careful and more professional.  Mr. Hillerman was developing Officer Chee more and more before he died -- there just wasn't enough time.
summary: Buy it; Read it; Enjoy it.

This is the first novel in the series and intorduces Joe Leaphorn.  TH always admitted that he made errors in his books, and there is a doozie in this one, but that doesn't detract from a good yarn.  This is my second reading of the book and I realize it is not up to the quality of his later works, but it is still enjoyable.  While I am still not satisfied with the way the story's climax is written, I urge any one who likes a fun-to-read mystery novel to read The Blessing Way.  After the first, you will be hooked.

My review should actually be 3 1/2 stars.  The book started off really well and I was thinking "This is going to be a good Hillerman novel".  Then suddenly Chee is investigaqting a possible homicide with no obvious clues and, without what I would call roadmaps, he comes out of somewhere and solves it.  I found that part to be unsettling and rather hard to take.  I am not going deeply into the storyline because I want others to get ithe book and decide for themselves whether it deserves a "TONY".  Having an officer in uniform but not wearing a sidearm is totally contrary to every law enforcement SOP I know.  I recognze that the story needed an unarmed officer, soooooooo.........  How the officer survives the danger is what takes this 2nd attempt down to 3 stars.  So--a good 4 stars in the beginning then down and down to 3, leaving a 3 1/2 average.  Now, Anne, I want to see a solid 5 with your next outing (and I would like to have The LT involved).
summary: The book started off really well and I was thinking "This is going to be a good Hillerman novel"

reviewText: After reading "Anne of Green Gables" -- which I especially enjoyed the second-half of -- I thought I might delight in more tales of Anne.  Sadly, these linked short stories are just so-so.  If you're a die-hard Anne fan, than you'll take pleasure in them.  I found them less than engaging, even though I like the characters and Avonlea itself.

Since I was a child I've loved "The Three Musketeers" and its sequels, "Twenty Years After" and "The Vicomte de Bragelonne".  They are among my favorite books of all, so I'm ever interested in a "new" book by Alexandre Dumas.  "The Black Tulip" was one of those books of his I'd not read, nor even heard of until recently.

The story is set in The Netherlands during the time of William of Orange (1670s).  It involves the civil unrest of the time, but is primarily concerned with Cornelius Van Baerle, who has no interest in politics and is devoted to his tulips (and his quest to create the first all-black blossom); Rosa, the plucky young woman who loves and helps him; and the scheming and wicked Isaac Boxtel, who labors to acquire the elusive black tulip for himself, stooping even to falsely imprison the naive Cornelius.

The story becomes surprisingly exciting, a true nail-biter even, and has the historical scenery, action, romance, and humor that draw me back to Dumas again and again.  I don't love "The Black Tulip" like I do "The Three Musketeers" and its sequels, but I still find much to enjoy in it, and I plan to return to the book again in the years to come.
summary: Two Cheers for The Black Tulip

reviewText:
Since I was a child I've loved "The Three Musketeers" and its sequels, "Twenty Years After" and "The Vicomte de Bragelonne".  They are among my favorite books of all, so I'm ever interested in a "new" book by Alexandre Dumas.  "The Black Tulip" was one of those books of his I'd not read, nor even heard of until recently.

The story is set in The Netherlands during the time of William of Orange (1670s).  It involves the civil unrest of the time, but is primarily concerned with Cornelius Van Baerle, who has no interest in politics and is devoted to his tulips (and his quest to create the first all-black blossom); Rosa, the plucky young woman who loves and helps him; and the scheming and wicked Isaac Boxtel, who labors to acquire the elusive black tulip for himself, stooping even to falsely imprison the naive Cornelius.

The story becomes surprisingly exciting, a true nail-biter even, and has the historical scenery, action, romance, and humor that draw me back to Dumas again and again.  I don't love "The Black Tulip" like I do "The Three Musketeers" and its sequels, but I still find much to enjoy in it, and I plan to return to the book again in the years to come.

One thing I'd like to add: if you want to make an organic version of Amish Friendship Bread, you can substitute Dr. Oetker Organics brand pudding in place of "Jell-O" brand. It can be difficult to discern the differences in the plethora of adventure titles that deal with arcane lore involving elements of the Christian faith. On some levels, "The Templar Legacy" seems like many others; a single, middle-aged man who has a special knowledge in an esoteric area finds himself in the middle of a life-and-death adventure. There's a treasure, a beautiful woman, and an evil man of the cloth. Berry's novel differs a bit from some others in that he spends more time on background history, character backstory, etc (which some might see as a negative). A big difference -- and a plus, in my opinion -- is the explanation at the end of the novel regarding what parts of the story are partially or wholly based in fact and what parts are made up. Berry gives names of scholars and titles of works cited (none of which is "Holy Blood, Holy Grail"). "The Templar Legacy" is a bit slower moving than some other adventure tales, but it is a good read for those interested in arcane church history (which must be a pretty big audience the way these books are selling!)
Excellent!
excellent!

reviewText: This book shows us again how much God wants to be in relationship with us. His desire is for us to be in deep, meaningful relationship with Him and others. For too long we've put God in a box of what we think He should be. Read this book and see for yourself and how God can work in your life---your messy garden!

My 6 year old was really struggling and didn't even want to try learning to read anymore. This book completely turned her around. If I forget to do a lesson, she brings it to me insisting that we do it. She has even chosen not to play with friends in order to be able to do her lesson! She felt completely helpless before (and so did we). Now she feels like she's capable and in control. We're more than halfway through the book and she's reading. We're incredibly proud of her and she's so proud of herself and her accomplishment. I'm not sure what we would have done if we hadn't bought this book. The difference in her skill level just a couple of months ago and now is staggering. Her writing and comprehension are improving too. Everyone with a reluctant reader should try this book.

Our kids went through about lesson 55, but then got bored and daunted by the long stories and relative paucity of pictures (just one small picture is included in each chapter.)  SO, the major failing is that this book, by itself, isn't really "fun" enough to hold our children's interest.  We supplemented it with "[...]" and "bob books first" and "scholastic early readers" books.  The headsprout stuff is so much fun that our kids are dying to play with it every day.  they also like to read the scholastic early readers.  we occasionally do a lesson from this book but ITS RELATIVELY BORING compared to other ways of teaching our kids.  Teaching should be "fun", there is not much "fun" in this book.

The biggest failing of this book is that it does not teach enough rules, and does not spend enough time educating the teacher in how to present.  for example, i found myself very frustrated because my kids did not know the "silent e" rules for decoding words, and they did not know what vowels were.  the book also does not have a list of phonemes or sub-phonemes that you could just make sure you kids know to pronounce together, sounds like "th", "sh", "gh", etc., cannot be easily understood by following the phonics rules in this book (at least, at chapter 55, they weren't.)  There are no self-assessment tests to ensure that your kids are prepared to go onwards.  All in all, the major weakness of this curriculum is that it requires a high degree of teaching skill to implement successfully, as there is very little curriculum theory in the book.

our kids can decode but what's really the problem is that they lack their own motivation to decode and read.  they will occasionally read things and try to spell things on their own, but they don't have the motivation to pick up an early reader book and get through the entire book, on their own, yet.  i do not think we are "pushing" our kids so much, as they just don't have the right stuff (and we don't have the time to design something from scratch) that makes reading "fun".

Our twin boys just turned 4 years old.  disclaimer: both parents are engineers, one with a ph.d.
summary: Good up to a point, but ...

reviewText: Words can kill. Words can save. Words can manipulate and torment. Words can redeem and restore. What will your words do for others? I've never thought about the power of words through the eyes of Death, WWII, nor the Holocaust. This is a powerful story.
Not an easy to read book.  very disturbing at times.  went to see the movie, but it was sold out.

reading this for the 2nd time, (it's been a while). excellent look at the 'brothers', history and origins of our fair land. good read
take notes!

This book is much less interesting than Ellis's three other "big ones", the biographies of Washington, Jefferson and Adams.  Why was this one given the Pulitzer prize?

The blurb for this book claims that it  represents a new interpretation of the revolutionary generation, reconceived as "Founding Brothers" rather than Founding Fathers.  But this is not borne out by the book, which reads like a collection of journal articles on miscellaneous subjects, rather than a unified thematic work.

Ellis's other books had a friendly, intelligent, companionable quality which kept me reading.  I looked forward to picking up the story where I left off.  In fact sometimes I even found it hard to stop reading, so gripping was the narrative and so new were the insights I was gaining into the emblematic names of the American pantheon.  But in reading this book I have been frequently bored.  The fact that each chapter stands on its own actually makes them harder to read - the chapters do not build on one another, yet sometimes they are redundant (and redundancy with Ellis's other books is frequent) - and chronological weirdness abounds - events treated in the first chapter took place many years AFTER the events in the second chapter, etc.

I wonder if Ellis was trying to be "postmodern" with this book - a big temptation for him I'm sure, since he is a good writer, well in command of his material, and surrounded on all sides by professional colleagues who value style and eccentricity over content.

I don't want to say that the book is not worth reading, but I would certainly place it last on the list among Ellis's excellent and justly celebrated works.
This is a fun book to read to,children, at home or school. It's fun and makes you smile. My daughter loved it.
My daughter loved this story that had a young child in it just like her. She enjoyed the pictures as well as the story.
Unfortunately her last:((
Not her best book but still an interesting read.  Sue, you can and have done better.
summary: Not the best book she has written

reviewText: Dumb plot, a waste of time unless you are going to use it as a guide to Florence. Don't they ever sit down, have a coffee or go to the bathroom?

Wow!  In this novel, Dan Brown leads us on a journey full of serpentine twists and turns, each of which had me thinking I had solved the ultimate mystery, but which led in another direction.  This is superb storytelling combined with another  educational journey through critical periods of art.  I recommend this for any reader.
An interesting and compelling.

We are returning to Italy with Robert Langdon and given a new lecture tour of the architecture.
Interesting but not as engrossing as Lost Symbol.
summary: Inferno is not as exciting as the Lost Symbol

reviewText: I loved this tale of an irreverent attorney who deals with the worst of the worst and somehow seems to succeed.  The plot twists furiously, and I could seldom keep up with the multiple cases and situations.  He's morally a good guy, but always keeps you guessing.
Thoroughly enjoyed this book. It's not a literary masterpiece, but I so enjoyed it. It twists and turns and keeps you interested. I don't want to give anything away but I highly recommend it.
Okay.....kind of dragged on....good ending though.

I had read other reviews that indicated that there weren't a lot of words in this book, but the "story" seemed cute so I thought I'd try it anyway.  The pictures really are very nice and the concept of the story was just as fun as I expected it would be.  After looking through it though I do think it could have done with more words.  I purchased it for a 1 year old so having just pictures isn't terrible, but I think the book would grow with a child more and be enjoyed for longer if it had some words and could be read rather than just looked at.
We love looking for the little mouse with the banana on each page! It's cute to hear my 2-year-old say, "Armadillo."

Too many characters, too many subplots, too many cupcakes.  It really was never explained why most of the "activities" occurred in Sophie's backyard.  Do big backyards have alleys behind them?  Methinks that perhaps the five star ratings came from the author's friends. Only Martha was halfway interesting.
I really like these books, and will continue to buy them as they become available. I enjoy good mysteries that don't have the realistic pain and suffering of children.
